'''Daniel Riquelme García''' ([[Santiago]], [[Chile]], 1857– [[Lausanne]], [[Switzerland]], 1912) was a writer, journalist and chronicler of [[Chile]].

==Biography==
He was a son of Jose Riquelme Orozco, the first Chilean [[stenography|stenographer]], and Bruna Garcia Venegas, a professor of music. He was the younger brother of Ernesto Riquelme. In 1865, his father died and his mother took over his education. He studied at the National Institute of Santiago, then law at the [[University of Chile]], although he subsequently abandoned his studies.

He began as a writer on various topics in [[Santiago]] magazines, and then devoted himself to journalism. In 1876 he entered public service, serving as auxiliary official of the Ministry of Finance under the government of President [[Aníbal Pinto]]. As public functionary he was part of an integrated civilian entourage that accompanied the [[Chilean Army]] during the [[War of the Pacific]], and he used his stay at the [[Front (military)|war front]] to work as a correspondent for ''El Heraldo'' of [[Valparaiso]], a newspaper that published his articles from November 1880 until June 1881.

In 1885 he published ''Military Chascarillos'', or ''Military Jokes'', which recounted his experiences at the front, dealing with topics such as jokes, table manners and various stories. The book was edited, enhanced and then republished in the work that made him most famous, ''Under the tent'' (1888).

From 1887 to 1891, Riqueme wrote stories, chronicles and articles under the [[pseudonym]] with which he popularly became known: Innocent Conchalí. During this period his works included his urban portraits of bohemian Santiago in the late nineteenth century, in particular around the Orphans, Merced and Recoleta streets, where he spent much of his life. His writings combined nascent modernism techniques with the metaphors and sayings drawn from the local Creole. This contributed to Chilean prose of the nineteenth century, and was adopted by later writers including [[Baldomero Lillo]] and [[Olegario Lazo Baeza]].

After the fall of President [[José Manuel Balmaceda]], Riquelme continued to work as a writer periodically, but abandoned his light and adorned style of writing to instead engage in works on various historical events, a task that continued during his years at the ''[[El Mercurio]]'' of Santiago until 1911.

Sick with [[tuberculosis]], Riqueme traveled to [[Paris]] and then moved to [[Switzerland]]. He died in [[Lausanne]] in 1912, and his remains were interred there until 1942, when they were thrown into a [[common grave]]. At present, the precise location of his remains is unknown.

==Work==
In addition to his work on the War of the Pacific, Riquelme portrayed the political and social life of Santiago in the late nineteenth century through articles on folklore, chronicles of the day, and various tales and short stories. In the latter stage of his career as an author, he wrote extensively on history, and he proposed a rereading of some of the foundational accounts of Chile.

* ''Military Chascarillos'' (1885)
* ''Under The Tent'' (1888)
* ''The Revolution of April 20, 1851'' (1893)
* ''The Church of the Company Fire: December 8, 1863'' (1893)
* ''Compendium of the History of Chile'' (1899)
* ''The earthquake Mr. May'' (1905)

==See also==
* [[Chilean literature]]

'''Thirumudivakkam''' is a south-western suburb of [[Chennai]] metropolitan city, Tamil Nadu. This area belongs to [[Sriperumbudur taluk]], Kanchipuram district.

It holds an industrial estate with around 350 MSME companies with varied production units supporting Automobile companies and many other at Sriperumbudur, Oragadam Industrial corridor and so on. Employers and employees are joining hands together for the upliftment of the nation economy through production. Greenery is the vision of Thirumudivakkam industrial estate.

Tamil Nadu Government State Esi dispensary was established recently on 2 July 2019 for the well being of the employees and their Families.

Thiruneermalai Perumal temple (one among the 108 Dhivyasthalam) is situated very near (6 km) by to this place.<ref>http://wikiedit.org/India/Thirumudivakkam/227207/</ref>

==Demographics==
According to 2011 Census of India, the total population of this village is 4083. The literacy rate of this village is 78.21%.<ref>http://www.census2011.co.in/data/village/629245-thirumudivakkam-tamil-nadu.html</ref>

'''Eudore Évanturel''' ([[Quebec (city)|Quebec]], 22 September 1852 – [[Boston]], 16 May 1919) is a Quebec poet, [[Canada]].

== Biography ==
Interested very early in poetry, he frequented clubs of young writers. In October [[1875]], his play \Crâne et cervelle\" was read before an audience in Quebec. The work
column5: which tells the story of a medical student who steals corpses to dissect them and who falls on the remains of his own fiancée
column6: is scandalous. The reaction will be just as lively in the following days with some of his poems published in the newspaper ''[[L'Évènement-Journal|L'Évènement]]''.

column1: Shaken but encouraged by the novelist [[Joseph Marmette]]
column3: Évanturel published in [[1878]] a volume of ''Premier poésies''. This collection
column4: inspired by [[Alfred de Musset|Musset]] but with accents [[Paul Verlaine|verlainiens]]
column5: still scandalizes the conservative literary milieu of [[Quebec]] at the time. The ruthless and unfair criticism of [[Jules-Paul Tardivel]] in particular closes doors for him and drives his friends away. He lost his job and even the support of Joseph Marmette. Thus dissuaded from going further in his career
column7: Évanturel went into exile in [[United States]] in [[Lowell
column8: Massachusetts|Lowell]] where he founded a French-language newspaper. He married in Quebec in [[1884]] Esther Casgrain and returned to settle in Quebec in [[1887]] where he died in [[1919]].

column1: The author only publishes a few isolated poems thereafter. He was however one of the first to deal with themes different from those in force at the time: wide open spaces
column4: etc. Évanturel tackles rather subjects which strike the ambient conservatism. He takes an observer position on art
column5: love
column8: social disparities
column12: he appears to be a pioneer who sought to break conventions. His work is still unknown
column13: but he is nonetheless one of the most sensitive
column14: original and inspired poets of Quebec before [[Émile Nelligan|Nelligan]].

'''Byron Tau''' is an American journalist at ''[[The Wall Street Journal]]''.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.wsj.com/news/author/byron-tau|title=Byron Tau - News, Articles, Biography, Photos  - WSJ.com|website=WSJ|language=en-US|access-date=2019-02-15}}</ref> He covers the [[United States Department of Justice|Department of Justice]] and was previously a White House reporter.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.cision.com/us/2014/11/wall-street-journal-welcomes-james-gaddy-and-byron-tau/|title=Wall Street Journal Welcomes James Gaddy And Byron Tau|date=2014-11-07|website=Cision|access-date=2019-02-15}}</ref>

== Early life and education ==
Tau graduated with a B.A. in political science and North American history from [[McGill University]] in 2008. He then completed an MA in journalism at [[Georgetown University]] in 2011.

== Career ==
Tau began his journalism career at ''[[Politico]]'' as a news assistant to [[Ben Smith (journalist)|Ben Smith]], helping him run his politics blog, before being made a fully-fledged reporter in 2011.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.adweek.com/digital/meet-byron-tau-ben-smiths-d-c-assistant/|title=Meet Byron Tau, Ben Smith's D.C. Assistant|website=www.adweek.com|language=en-US|access-date=2019-02-15}}</ref> His remit included covering national politics, including the 2012 presidential campaign, and the White House.

He left ''Politico'' in 2014 to join ''The Wall Street Journal'' as a [[White House]] reporter in time for the [[2016 United States presidential election|2016 presidential election]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.adweek.com/digital/politicos-byron-tau-to-wall-street-journal/|title=POLITICO's Byron Tau to Wall Street Journal|website=www.adweek.com|language=en-US|access-date=2019-02-15}}</ref> After the election, Tau began writing about national security issues as Capitol Hill Correspondent for ''The Journal''.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://talkingbiznews.com/1/wsj-reporter-tau-moving-to-justice-department-and-fbi-beat/|title=WSJ reporter Tau moving to Justice Department and FBI beat - Talking Biz News|website=talkingbiznews.com|access-date=2019-02-15}}</ref> He regularly appears on radio and television networks, including [[WNYC-FM|WNYC]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.wnyc.org/people/byron-tau/|title=People - Byron Tau {{!}} WNYC {{!}} New York Public Radio, Podcasts, Live Streaming Radio, News|website=WNYC|language=en|access-date=2019-02-15}}</ref> and [[C-SPAN]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.c-span.org/person/?byrontau|title=Byron Tau {{!}} C-SPAN.org|website=www.c-span.org|access-date=2019-02-15}}</ref>

Tau is considered among the lead writers at ''The Journal'' covering the investigation into Russian interference in the 2016 election and obstruction of justice by special counsel [[Robert Mueller|Robert S. Mueller III]].

'''David Ablett''' (4 February 1941 – 24 July 2010) was a Canadian journalist and editor for ''[[The Vancouver Sun]]'', the ''[[Toronto Star]]'', and other media. He was born in [[Gibson's Landing, British Columbia]], Canada.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.legacy.com/can-vancouver/Obituaries.asp?page=lifestory&personid=144329376|title=David Ablett|accessdate=2010-07-28}}</ref>

Ablett attended the [[University of British Columbia]] for his undergraduate studies. At the University of British Columbia he started his journalism career as the editorial page editor of the student newspaper, ''[[The Ubyssey]]''. After university, he worked as a journalist at the ''Vancouver Sun''.

In 1965, the ''Vancouver Sun'' sent him to [[Columbia University]] School of Journalism, where he graduated in 1967 and he was awarded the [[Pulitzer Prize]] Traveling Fellowship.

The prize allowed him to spend the next two years abroad - first in Japan, where he worked as a journalist for the ''[[Asahi Shimbun]]'', then Europe, where he covered the Soviet invasion of Czechoslovakia for [[Radio Free Europe]].

He returned to the ''Vancouver Sun'' in 1969 and became the Washington, and then Ottawa Bureau Chief. He then became the ''Vancouver Sun'''s editorial page editor.

In 1977, while at the ''Vancouver Sun'', Ablett won Canada's National Newspaper Award for editorial writing.

Later, he joined the [[Privy Council for Canada]] where he served as speech writer and special adviser to Canadian Prime Minister [[Pierre Elliott Trudeau]].

In 1982, Trudeau appointed David to the [[Royal Commission on the Economic Union and Development Prospects for Canada]] headed by [[Donald Stovel Macdonald]].  David was Joint Editorial Head along with [[Michel Vastel]].

Ablett then went on to work at the [[Bank of Montreal]] and then the [[Bank of Nova Scotia]] where he became head of Public Affairs. 
He later joined the editorial board of the ''[[Toronto Star]]''.

He eventually finished his career at the [[Toronto Stock Exchange]] where he retired as VP of Public and Corporate Affairs in 2007.

David Ablett died on July 24, 2010, in Peterborough, Ontario.

{{Infobox person | name = Brahim Riahi | image = | alt = | caption = | other_names = إبراهيم الرياحي | birth_name = Abou Ishak Ibrahim Ben Abdelkader Riahi | birth_date = 1766 | birth_place = [[Testour]], [[Tunisia]] | death_date = August 7, 1850 | death_place = | nationality = Tunisian | occupation = | years_active = | known_for = | notable_works = }} '''Ibrahim Riahi,''' his birth name '''Abou Ishak Ibrahim Ben Abdelkader Riahi''' (1766 [[Testour]] – August 7, 1850){{Cite web|url=https://data.bnf.fr/fr/14651143/ibrahim_ibn__abd_al-qadir_al-_riyah_i/|title=Ibrāhīm ibn ʿAbd al-Qādir al- Riyāḥī (1767-1850)|website=data.bnf.fr|access-date=2020-04-13}}, was a [[Tunisia|Tunisian]] ambassador, theologian and saint. A Sunni Muslim scholar, he is also a poet. He is the grandfather of [[Ali Riahi]]. == Biography == Ibrahim Riahi learned about the group of academics and lawyers from Tunisia, in particular: Hamza Al-Jibas, Saleh Al-Kawash, Muhammad Al-Fassi, Omar Bin Qassem Al-Mahjoub, Hassan Al-Sharif, Ahmed Bou Khurais, Ismail Al -Tamimi, Al-Taher Ben Massoud, and others.{{Citation|title=إبراهيم الرياحي|date=2020-01-27|url=https://ar.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=%D8%A5%D8%A8%D8%B1%D8%A7%D9%87%D9%8A%D9%85_%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%B1%D9%8A%D8%A7%D8%AD%D9%8A&oldid=43176304|work=ويكيبيديا|language=ar|access-date=2020-04-13}} Sidi Brahim frequented from a young age a kouttab in [[Testour]] and showed talent for religious sciences and learning the [[Quran]]. Upon his arrival in [[Tunis]], around 1782, he studied at the Haouanet Achour madrassah and then at the Bir Lahjar madrassah.{{Cite web|url=http://web.archive.org/web/20080302042056/http://www.tunisia.strabon.org/amvppc/Tunis/Dossier%20Patrimoine/10zaouia_fr.html|title=Tourba et Zaouiya: Le mythe ...|date=2008-03-02|website=web.archive.org|access-date=2020-04-13}} Around 1790, he began teaching at Zitouna University where the future ministers Ibn Abi Dhiaf and Béji Messaoudi as well as the greatest theologians of the time such as Mohamed Bayram IV and Mahmoud Kabadou were among his students. In 1801, he was part of an embassy in [[Morocco]], where he stayed for several months, there he discovered the Sufi tariqa of the Tijaniyya and introduced it to Tunisia on his return.{{Citation|title=Sidi Brahim Riahi|date=2020-01-23|url=https://fr.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Sidi_Brahim_Riahi&oldid=166662511|work=Wikipédia|language=fr|access-date=2020-04-13}} == Sidi Brahim Riahi Mausoleum == Sidi Brahim is buried with some of his sons, sheikhs and theologians like him, in his mausoleum in the Sidi Brahim Riahi street in the medina of Tunis named [[Sidi Brahim Riahi Mausoleum]]. [[File:Sidi Brahim Riahi Mausoleum - mausolée Sidi Brahim Riahi - زاوية سيدي ابراهيم الرياحي photo2.jpg|thumb|Dome zaouia Sidi Brahim Riahi]]

'''Israel Pliner''' ({{lang-ru|Израиль Израилевич Плинер}}, '''Izrail Izrailevich Pliner''') (1896–1939) was a Soviet communist and high functionary of the [[Soviet secret police]] . Notable posts include deputy chief of [[GULAG|GULAGS]]<ref>{{Cite book|last=Congdon|first=Lee|url=https://books.google.ca/books?id=oK68DwAAQBAJ&pg=PT169&dq=Israel+Pliner&hl=en&sa=X&redir_esc=y#v=onepage&q=Israel%20Pliner&f=false|title=Solzhenitsyn: The Historical-Spiritual Destinies of Russia and the West|date=2017-09-15|publisher=Cornell University Press|isbn=978-1-60909-224-5|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|last=Baberowski|first=Jörg|url=https://books.google.ca/books?id=DqFTDQAAQBAJ&pg=PT148&dq=Israel+Pliner&hl=en&sa=X&redir_esc=y#v=onepage&q=Israel%20Pliner&f=false|title=Scorched Earth: Stalin's Reign of Terror|date=2016-11-22|publisher=Yale University Press|isbn=978-0-300-22057-5|language=en}}</ref> in (1935-1937) and  (1937-1938). 

He was one of the main collaborators of [[Nikolai Yezhov]], head of the [[NKVD]] in the years 1936–1938, and collaborator of other organizers of the [[Great Purge|Great Terror in the USSR]]. 

On August 16, 1937, he became the head of the board of the communist concentration camps GULAG [[NKVD]] five days after the beginning of [[Polish Operation of the NKVD]]. According to NKVD documents, 139,835 Poles who were citizens of the USSR were convicted in 1937. Of this number, 111 091 Poles were directly killed, and 28 744 Poles were sent to communist [[Gulag|GULAG]] concentration camps.

In 1937, he directed the deportation of 172,000 Korean citizens of the USSR from the Soviet Far East to Central Asia (to Kazakhstan and Uzbekistan).

He was arrested in 1938 and executed in 1939.<ref>[http://hrono.ru/biograf/bio_p/plinerii.php \Плинер Израиль Израилевич\"] at hrono.ru

'''Eudore Évanturel''' ([[Quebec (city)|Quebec]], 22 September 1852 – [[Boston]], 16 May 1919) is a Quebec poet, [[Canada]].

== Biography ==
Interested very early in poetry, he frequented clubs of young writers. In October [[1875]], his play \Crâne et cervelle\" was read before an audience in Quebec. The work
column5: which tells the story of a medical student who steals corpses to dissect them and who falls on the remains of his own fiancée
column6: is scandalous. The reaction will be just as lively in the following days with some of his poems published in the newspaper ''[[L'Évènement-Journal|L'Évènement]]''.

column1: Shaken but encouraged by the novelist [[Joseph Marmette]]
column3: Évanturel published in [[1878]] a volume of ''Premier poésies''. This collection
column4: inspired by [[Alfred de Musset|Musset]] but with accents [[Paul Verlaine|verlainiens]]
column5: still scandalizes the conservative literary milieu of [[Quebec]] at the time. The ruthless and unfair criticism of [[Jules-Paul Tardivel]] in particular closes doors for him and drives his friends away. He lost his job and even the support of Joseph Marmette. Thus dissuaded from going further in his career
column7: Évanturel went into exile in [[United States]] in [[Lowell
column8: Massachusetts|Lowell]] where he founded a French-language newspaper. He married in Quebec in [[1884]] Esther Casgrain and returned to settle in Quebec in [[1887]] where he died in [[1919]].

column1: The author only publishes a few isolated poems thereafter. He was however one of the first to deal with themes different from those in force at the time: wide open spaces
column4: etc. Évanturel tackles rather subjects which strike the ambient conservatism. He takes an observer position on art
column5: love
column8: social disparities
column12: he appears to be a pioneer who sought to break conventions. His work is still unknown
column13: but he is nonetheless one of the most sensitive
column14: original and inspired poets of Quebec before [[Émile Nelligan|Nelligan]].

'''Axilliary dissection''' is a [[surgical procedure]] that incises the [[axilla]], usually in order to identify, examine, or take out [[lymph nodes]].<ref>{{cite book |title=The Dorling Kindersley illustrated family encyclopedia. |year=2002 |url=https://archive.org/details/dkillustratedfam00kind |url-access=registration |publisher=Dorling Kindersley |isbn=9780789488657}}</ref> The term \axilla\" refers to the armpit or underarm section of the body.<ref name=\":2\">{{Cite web|url=https://www.breastcancer.org/treatment/surgery/lymph_node_removal/axillary_dissection|title=Axillary Lymph Node Dissection|date=2018-09-19|website=Breastcancer.org|language=en|access-date=2020-04-07}}</ref> The axillary dissection procedure is commonly used in treating the underarm portion of women who are dealing with breast cancer.<ref name=\":0\">{{Cite journal|date=2020-01-17|title=Axillary Dissection: Overview
column5: Periprocedural Care
column6: Technique|url=https://emedicine.medscape.com/article/1894763-overview}}</ref> The lymph nodes located in the axilla area that are affected by breast cancer are called the guardian or sentinel lymph nodes. Patients tend to have three different levels of axillary lymph nodes; the level helps to determine whether or not the patient should undergo axillary dissection.

column3: then it may not be necessary for the patient to undergo the axillary dissection procedure. However
column4: if a patient contains at least three or more affected guardian lymph nodes
column5: then a physician will recommend that the patient undergo axillary dissection.<ref name=\":1\" />

column1: == The Three Levels of Axillary Lymph Nodes ==

There are three different levels of axillary lymph nodes. Level I refers to lymph nodes located below the axillary vein or towards the very bottom end of the pectoralis minor muscle. Level II refers to lymph nodes located directly under the [[Pectoralis minor|pectoralis minor muscle]]. Level III refers to lymph nodes that are located over the pectoralis minor muscle and would require an intense procedure. Typically lymph nodes located in Levels I and II are removed with the axillary dissection. A mastectomy may also have to accompany this procedure in some cases depending on the patient.<ref name=\":2\" />

{{Wills, trusts, estates}}
In [[law]], '''Incorporation by reference''' is the act of including a second [[document]] within another document by only mentioning the second document.<ref>{{cite book|title=Black's Law Dictionary|editor=Bryan A. Garner|publisher=West Group|location=St. Paul, MN|date=2001|edition=2nd pocket|page=341|isbn=0-314-25791-8}}</ref> This act, if properly done, makes the entire second document a part of the main document. Incorporation by reference is often done in creating laws as well as in [[Contract|contract law]] and [[Property law|trust and estate law]].

In law regarding [[Will and testament|wills]], it is a doctrine at [[common law]] which allows a testator, or a creator of a will, to dispose of assets in his estate in accordance with a separate document. To be valid, such a document must comply with the following requirements:
# it must have existed at the time the will was executed;
# the will must describe the document with particularity, so that it may be identified; and
# the will must clearly manifest the intent that the document be incorporated.
An exception to the first requirement is made for small gifts of tangible [[personal property]], such as household furniture and items of sentimental value.

Oral instructions can ''not'' be subject to incorporation by reference. For example, if a [[testator]] states in the will that he has recited to a third party the intended disposition of testamentary assets, such attempt to circumvent the requirements of a written will is [[Void (law)|void]].

In American [[administrative law]], incorporation by reference is a drafting tool that enables federal agencies to give legal effect to materials that are already published elsewhere.  This is allowed under a provision of [[Freedom of Information Act (United States)|the Freedom of Information Act]], 5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(1).  Section 552(a) requires agencies to publish regulations in the [[Federal Register]] in order to enforce them.  Section 552(a)(1) provides that if material published elsewhere is \reasonably available to the class of persons affected\" and the Director of the Federal Register approves its incorporation by reference
column5: that material will be \"deemed published\" in the Federal Register.  It is most controversially used to incorporate privately authored voluntary consensus standards into health and safety regulations without infringing the standards developers' copyright.  Federal law and policy
column6: embodied in the [[National Technology Transfer and Advancement Act]] of 1995 and [[Office of Management and Budget]] (OMB) Circular A-119
column7: requires federal agencies to use these standards instead of creating \"government-unique\" technical standards purely to serve regulatory purposes.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Bremer|first=Emily S.|title=Incorporation by Reference in an Open-Government Age|journal=Harvard Journal of Law and Public Policy|year=2013|volume=36|issue=1|page=131|ssrn=2127288}}</ref>

==Biography==
Makamba posted commentary on Zimbabwean politics and society online under the heading \State of the Nation\"

'''Mainflingen''' is a district of [[Mainhausen]], in the [[Offenbach (district)|district of Offenbach]] in [[Hesse]] with about 4000 inhabitants. It is known for its time signal transmitter, [[DCF77]],  which controls almost all radio clocks in [[Western Europe]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.mainhausen.de/zeitsender|title=Der Zeitsender DCF77 in Mainflingen|language=de|trans-title=The radio clock DCF77 in Mainflingen|author=<!--Not stated-->|website=Mainhausen.de|publisher=City of Mainhausen|access-date=11 May 2018}}</ref>

==Geography==
===Location===
Mainflingen is a municipality of the town [[Mainhausen]], which lies in the [[Offenbach (district)|Offenbach district]], located in the southernmost part of the state [[Hesse]] right on the border with [[Bavaria]]. It lies near the river [[Main (river)|Main]].

===Constituent communities===
Mainflingen is one of the two constituent communities of Mainhausen, the other one is [[Zellhausen]].

==History==
Mainflingen was first mentioned in a document from the year 775. In this and other documents from 793, 796 and 799 it is confirmed that citizens of the municipality Manolfingen bequeathed fields and meadows to the monastery [[Lorsch Abbey|Lorsch]]. Researchers believe that the name is not derived from the river Main, but from a man named Manolf and his ancestors.<ref name= \OP\">{{cite news|last=Signus|first=Oliver|date=16 September 2015|title=Mainflingen vor 1240 Jahren erstmals urkundlich erwähnt|trans-title=Mainflingen was first mentioned in a document 1240 years ago|url=https://www.op-online.de/region/mainhausen/mainflingen-wurde-1240-jahren-erstmals-urkundlich-erwaehnt-5530053.html|language=German|work=Offenbach-Post|access-date=11 May 2018}}</ref>

As a direct consequence of the [[Thirty Years' War]]
column2: Mainflingen and the surrounding communities had suffered severe population losses.<ref name= \"OP\"/>

'''David Scearce''' is a lawyer and screenwriter.

==Career==

===Law===
Scearce earned a business degree from [[Wilfrid Laurier University]] and a law degree from the [[University of British Columbia]] before joining the [[Department of Justice (Canada)|Justice Department]].<ref name=clerk>{{cite web|url=http://www.clerk.gc.ca/eng/prsns.asp?featureID=0&pageID=196&prsnID=36&thmID=0&dptmntID=0|title=David Scearce|publisher=[[Clerk of the Privy Council (Canada)|Clerk of the Privy Council]]|date=27 September 2012|accessdate=29 April 2014}}</ref>

===Film===
In 2000, Scearce decided to write screenplays in his spare time.<ref name=clerk/><ref name=globe>{{cite web|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/arts/david-scearce-white-collar-by-day-red-carpet-by-night/article4188558/|title= David Scearce: White collar by day, red carpet by night |date=4 December 2009|work=[[The Globe and Mail]] |first=Marsha|last=Lederman|accessdate=29 April 2014}}</ref> One of his first attempts was an adaptation of a favourite novel—''A Single Man'' by [[Christopher Isherwood]]. [[Don Bachardy]], Isherwood's surviving partner who managed the rights to the story, approved of the script and it was then picked up by fashion designer and first-time film director [[Tom Ford]]. ''[[A Single Man]]'', starring [[Colin Firth]] and [[Julianne Moore]], premiered at the [[Venice Film Festival]] in September 2009 and was released in December 2009.<ref name=straight>{{cite web|url=https://www.straight.com/movies/vancouverite-david-scearce-succeeds-single-man-screenplay |date=22 December 2009 |work=[[The Georgia Straight]] |title=Vancouverite David Scearce succeeds with A Single Man screenplay |first=Ken |last=Eisner |accessdate=29 April 2014 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140429205201/http://www.straight.com/movies/vancouverite-david-scearce-succeeds-single-man-screenplay |archivedate=29 April 2014 }}</ref>  It and its cast and crew received critical acclaim as well as numerous awards and nominations, including a [[Critics' Choice Movie Award]] nomination for Best Screenplay and an [[Independent Spirit Award]] nomination for [[Independent Spirit Award for Best First Screenplay|Best First Screenplay]].<ref name=globe/>

Scearce's second film adaptation, ''[[Measure of a Man (film)|Measure of a Man]]'', a [[coming-of-age story]] based on [[Robert Lipsyte]]'s novel ''[[One Fat Summer]]'', starring [[Blake Cooper]] and [[Donald Sutherland]], was released in 2018.[https://www.imdb.com/title/tt2670882/releaseinfo]

In 2018, Scearce was hired by the Michael Grandage Company to write an adaptation of ''Jack and Lem'', a biography by David Pitts about President [[John F. Kennedy]] and his gay best friend, [[Lem Billings]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.playbill.com/article/michael-grandage-to-helm-movie-adaptation-of-jack-and-lem|title=Michael Grandage to Helm Movie Adaptation of Jack and Lem|last=Clement|first=Olivia|date=25 July 2018|website=Playbill|language=en|access-date=2019-07-21}}</ref>
